title: Episode 133 – Aaron Perry – Reflections, Updates, & Musings upon an Auspicious Milestone
subtitle: RESOURCES & RELATED PODCAST EPISODES
description: Video – Aaron Perry shares 50+ daily sustainability practices with Wilson Sonsini Law Firm
full_transcript:
[10.0s - 29.3s]: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And this is our 133rd episode. I thought given the special nature of this number, which I'll share with you a little later on in the episode.

[30.0s - 53.2s]: It would be an opportune time, perhaps even an auspicious time, to come out you directly and share a number of reflections and updates, having now published 132 episodes and making this our 133rd.

[53.2s - 83.2s]: We've had the opportunity to interview so many thoughtful and impactful authors and scientists, indigenous wisdom keepers, farmers, herbalists, executives, youth activists, and myriad others who are engaged one way or another in what we like to call the regenerative.

[85.5s - 102.8s]: I'll tell you a bit about how we've been framing the regeneration renaissance as well as it really encompasses virtually all aspects of our human experience and doings on planet earth in these momentous times.

[104.0s - 119.6s]: We've got so many new resources to share with you as well and updates on a number of really exciting projects in development that will be rolling out in the coming weeks and months.

[121.4s - 137.8s]: So maybe to dive in, I'll share with you that as you probably can tell by the background if you're watching the video and perhaps here by the rain drops if you're listening that it's a rainy day.

[138.8s - 159.1s]: And no, I'm not currently in the Pacific Northwest, although this kind of weather certainly takes me back to my early childhood and roots where I froliced in the woods for hours in that incredibly lush and fertile part of the world.

[160.1s - 172.1s]: No, this is actually Colorado, not too far from Elkhruhn Farm and the town aligns the city of Boulder and a little farther away, the larger city of Denver.

[172.7s - 189.0s]: Just up in the foothills here and we're having an usually wet rainy several days, which is most welcome for many of our farming and gardening friends getting the soils, the plants, the plants, the plants.

[189.1s - 195.9s]: The starts freshly planted a really good drink of mama gaias nourishing waters.

[198.1s - 211.4s]: And a shout out speaking of Elkhruhn Farm, a big shout out to Nick D. Diminico and Marissa Polowski who run the farm and run drylands agro ecology research.

[212.4s - 238.0s]: And they in partnership with our friends, Audrey, Wycoff and others at the yellow barn farm nearby actually planted some 10,000 trees in partnership with the one tree planted organization and several others converging hundreds of folks getting together to plant thousands of trees to help restore regenerate the landscapes.

[238.0s - 246.7s]: And that's one of the three major pillars that we think about when we're doing our regeneration renaissance work.

[247.2s - 257.5s]: We've got the ecology, which includes agriculture includes taking good care of soil and water and plants and trees are in virons.

[257.5s - 277.8s]: We've also got culture and this of course includes how we interact with each other and I'll be speaking a little more about that sharing some of the insights and learnings I've had over the last several weeks and months with our podcast guests and other collaborating individuals and organizations.

[277.8s - 293.9s]: And in addition to culture, we also have economy. We have the machinery, the machinations, the design, the architecture, if you will, of our economic and financial systems.

[293.9s - 318.9s]: And when we're engaged deeply in this regeneration work, we come to understand that all three of those ecology, culture and economy are so intimately interconnected, especially right now for our species in particular having such a profound impact on the living bio-stere of planet earth and of course on one another.

[319.5s - 326.4s]: For better or worse, in many cases it's worse than it could be. We'll speak to that a little bit as well.

[327.4s - 348.8s]: So I'm out here enjoying this beautiful rainy day and I've been very thoughtful in preparation for this 133rd episode to share with you in a way that allows me to perhaps open up a little more than I often do when I'm interviewing another guest and share some of my not only thoughts but share with you.

[348.8s - 360.9s]: And perhaps even some of the more vulnerable aspects of some of the thoughts and feelings that I've had as of late and have from time to time doing this kind of work.

[363.8s - 389.4s]: As I mentioned Nick and Marissa, I gotta mention too that we of course had two beautiful podcasts with them, one with each, the his and hers episodes last fall at Elk Run Farm when the gardens were in full, bountiful bloom just before, a few weeks before in fact we got our first frosts and snows and knocked that back for the winter months.

[389.4s - 402.8s]: And of course now it's springtime and we've just come through the season of Belting, the eclipses that occurred and recording this right around the time of Mother's Day.

[403.6s - 415.1s]: It's such a wonderful time to give thanks for the fertility, the fecundity, the abundance we experience on this planet especially come springtime.

[415.1s - 421.9s]: Whether we're in the northern or the southern hemisphere we have a springtime on an annual seasonal basis.

[422.8s - 440.1s]: And in the northern hemisphere it's spring right now and just a great time to reflect and deepen into our awareness of our gratitude and even our love for the living planet we get to appreciate and enjoy.

[440.1s - 451.4s]: And of course that gives us life. And I think gratitude and love are really at the core of all this work that we're doing.

[452.2s - 461.0s]: And I find that the cultivation of love and gratitude is fundamentally the task at hand, the work we have before us.

[461.0s - 482.9s]: Regardless of our other areas of inquiry and perhaps expertise and endeavor, regardless of whether we're working in the realm of technology or finance or farming or herbal medicine or another holistic modality for healing or some other professional pursuit.

[482.9s - 498.0s]: We all, I believe, have the opportunity in all of this at this time to really deepen into our practices of cultivating on a daily basis this deep love and gratitude.

[498.9s - 508.0s]: And so with that I'll glance at my notes from time to time and just make sure that I share with you the things that I wanted to share with this episode.

[509.1s - 519.3s]: And I've brought a handful of books and some of the very special partner products that we have in our ecosystem of collaboration for you.

[519.3s - 529.0s]: And maybe I'll start there and mention that we've now got such a beautiful partnership with Chelsea Green Publishing.

[529.9s - 546.1s]: And they are a fabulous boutique press working with a number of authors engaged in this regenerative work from farming and gardening to working with food and also around economics and culture.

[546.9s - 556.9s]: We just recently had the opportunity to interview Ben Raskin with his wood chip handbook and that episode will be coming out relatively soon.

[557.2s - 565.8s]: So keep your eye out for that. That was just a wonderful discussion about how we can all incorporate wood chips into our gardening and farming efforts.

[565.8s - 573.5s]: Roy Seibag's new book, The Natural Order of Money is Hot Off the Press from Chelsea Green.

[574.4s - 585.6s]: And by the way, you can get a 35% discount on all the Chelsea Green books and audio books through the Y on earth.org website through the partners and supporters page.

[585.6s - 599.9s]: You'll see a number of our collaborating partners you can click right through and go shopping at a great discount from our friends at Chelsea Green or just use the code Y-O-E-3-5-at-chelsie-green.com.

[600.2s - 607.3s]: And you can get the books there. So yeah, this upcoming chat with Roy about the natural order of money is going to be wonderful.

[608.5s - 620.4s]: And we've also got a chat coming up with Maria Rodale, Love, Nature and Magic. And I'm really looking forward to this episode.

[620.6s - 633.0s]: It's such a joy to have begun reading her beautiful book. And of course, she comes from a family that's had tremendous impact in the organic and regenerative farming and land stewardship movement.

[633.0s - 656.3s]: Her grandfather apparently coined the term organic farming. And her father, as I understand it, coined the term regenerative farming. And so this is a beautiful, beautiful work of love from Maria, sharing some of her insights with her very personal and intimate relationships with different plants in her garden.

[656.3s - 679.5s]: So that'll be a great one to share. And we've also had the opportunity to interview some other wonderful folks like Georgia Kelly, for instance, who runs an annual excursion to the Mondragon cooperatives in the Basque region of Spain.

[679.5s - 697.8s]: And coming up in September is the next trip. There are still a couple of spots available. I'm planning to go. And the Mondragon cooperatives in case you're not aware are one of the most important examples of what regenerative economics can look like at scale.

[697.8s - 721.6s]: And so, founded in the 1950s, it has blossomed into an organization that includes something around 90,000 worker owner members. And as a conglomerate of different businesses, democratically and worker owned, democratically governed and worker owned.

[721.6s - 737.5s]: And they're now doing somewhere in the vicinity of $25 billion a year in sales and have a beautiful educational arm, a beautiful agriculture arm, land stewardship, climate response work is coming there, culinary school, all kinds of things.

[737.5s - 760.8s]: So really looking forward to sharing the episode with Georgia Kelly with you. And if you want to join and have some time in September to make an excursion over to Europe, or if you're already in Europe and want to meet up with us there, get in touch and we'll save you a spot if there's one still available.

[762.0s - 781.4s]: We've also had the opportunity to interview Nishup Palos, the new executive director of regenerative rising. And they're doing such important work all around the world of women led organization engaged deeply in this regenerative work, really looking forward to sharing that episode with you as well.

[781.4s - 807.2s]: And similarly with Tom Chee, this is our second interview with Tom and he's got an update on his view into the near and midterm economic developments around the global regenerative movement thinking in terms of three epochs that we're designing for and deploying both technology and heart centered practices in order to achieve together.

[807.2s - 826.7s]: We're really looking forward to hearing from Tom. His organization at one venture says already deployed somewhere around $150 million in sustainability technologies. And they're nearly closed on a second fund looking to deploy about twice that 300 million.

[827.5s - 856.7s]: We also interviewed two A. E. New Bakke, one of the indigenous chiefs and wisdom keepers from Amazonia coming at us from the verdant jungles of that part of the world and sharing with us why it's so important for us to connect ourselves with the forests, the green living plants, and also why it's so important for us to engage even more profoundly in our stewardship globally speaking of the world.

[856.7s - 875.9s]: The Amazon is such a critical and major ecological preserve of biodiversity that is providing life to our whole planet and really excited to share two ways interview with you as well.

[876.7s - 896.6s]: Also, we're going to be chatting soon with Matthew Fox, who of course has written many books and including several about Hildegard Funbingen. I am so enjoying reading this one called a Saint for Our Times Unleashing Her Power in the 21st century.

[896.6s - 918.1s]: Of course, the term Viriditas, which is the name of my novel, is a term that was coined by Hildegard Funbingen. And it means something along the lines of the green healing energy of the divine that flows through plants all across the biosphere.

[918.1s - 936.4s]: And I love reflecting on the abundance that comes to us from the solar radiance our sun is continuously streaming onto our planet earth, something like 173,000 terawatts of energy.

[936.4s - 965.4s]: And our biosphere through photosynthesis essentially is harvesting a little over 1% of that inbound energy, animating all of the life on this planet. Of course, there are some exceptions, some different critters at the deep sea vents and elsewhere and sub-aquias sub-terranean environments that don't receive sunlight and art connected directly to the photosynthetic cycle.

[966.4s - 980.6s]: And I love the feeling of nutrients and energy, but by and large virtually all of us living on earth are alive thanks to the plants and their magical ability to transform sunlight into food.

[982.0s - 1010.6s]: And as a celebration of our 133rd episode, I want to share the code with you, Gratis, g-r-a-t-i-s. You can use the code to get any of our e-books for free, including Y-on Earth, the non-fiction foundational tome explaining the myriad strategies and opportunities we have in our own lives to enhance our health and wellness, our prosperity, our thriving for our planet earth.

[1010.6s - 1026.6s]: Our homes, our families, and our neighborhoods and communities, while also exploring in a very comprehensive manner, the interconnected strategies we have for global stewardship, regeneration and sustainability.

[1027.3s - 1039.8s]: And so VeridiTos, Y-on Earth, our children's books, our soil stewardship handbook, all of these are available to you for free if you'd like to download the e-book versions using that code Gratis, g-r-a-t-i-s.

[1039.9s - 1045.7s]: And of course Y-on Earth is also available as an audiobook and you can use the same code to get that, if you'd like.

[1045.7s - 1060.5s]: Soon we'll have VeridiTos as an audiobook as well, and our dear friend, my dear friend, Brigitte Mars, who's on our Global Advisory Board, is just about finished reading the audiobook for us.

[1061.1s - 1073.1s]: And I think it's so fitting that she's the one reading it, in part because the protagonist is a super smart woman named Brigitte Sophia.

[1073.1s - 1082.0s]: And such a joy to have Brigitte Mars reading it for us, and I want to give her a shout out as well as our entire board.

[1082.5s - 1101.0s]: And Brigitte's on our Global Advisory Board has our many other wonderful leaders, including Bernard Amade, the founder of Engineers Without Borders and John Perkins, the author of Confessions of an Economic Hitman, as well as touching the Jaguar.

[1101.0s - 1107.0s]: And many, many others, and a very special things, of course, to our executive board.

[1107.4s - 1113.4s]: That's Artem Nikolkov, Katie Ross Garcis, and Brad Lidge.

[1114.3s - 1120.8s]: A huge shout out to all you guys for all you do for the Y-on Earth community and the work that we're doing.

[1122.1s - 1133.7s]: So when we talk about the regeneration renaissance, you know, we can deepen into our understanding, not only our understanding, but also our action-taking.

[1134.2s - 1141.0s]: We'd like to describe the Y-on Earth community as an action-oriented educational, nonprofit organization.

[1142.0s - 1157.0s]: So when we're working on the ecology pillar of the regeneration renaissance, the focus on water and soil and restoration and stewardship, and of course the detoxification of our environment is paramount, essential.

[1158.0s - 1185.8s]: And when we're focused on our economy, we have the opportunity to deepen in our understanding of how equity and fairness stewardship versus exploitation, for example, the institutionalization of care and kindness is right at our fingertips with the strategies and structures and techniques that we and so many of our colleagues around the world are engaged in developing and deploying and scaling up.

[1186.8s - 1212.9s]: And we'll be talking more and more in the near term about the quintenery and how that function within our understanding of the economic value chains that work in our world will help us reorient and pivot our economic and financial activities toward a much kinder, gentler life supporting and human supporting way of doing business together.

[1214.3s - 1234.0s]: On that note, I am so excited to share that we've got another book in the works, and this book is actually focused on very concrete, very practical strategies for regenerative finance, social enterprise, stewardship, philanthropy, and eco-scene economics.

[1234.0s - 1256.5s]: And for this project, in addition to the recommendations and case studies that I'm putting together with the team, we also have a number of essays from contributing guest authors, and these are thought leaders and organizational leaders who have so much wisdom and insight to share with us as we're engaged in this great pivot together.

[1256.5s - 1272.8s]: So really excited to share that with you. Right now the working title is the biggest deal. It's a bit of a tongue in cheek title that we explain in the introduction and assuming it publishes under that title, you can keep an eye out for that in the coming months.

[1274.1s - 1300.3s]: You know, we've so far this year already hosted something like 15 events and participated in a handful of others right at the beginning of January on what's called the Feast of the Epiphany in certain traditions is a time in the biodynamic tradition when we do a three kings preparation, biodynamic preparation, stir ceremony for the land.

[1300.3s - 1312.8s]: And we did this out at Elk Run Farm. And this is when we stir in the Frankenstein Sand Mer and Trace Gold to reaffirm our commitment of stewardship to the land where we're situated.

[1313.4s - 1323.4s]: You can do this on your own, whether you're in an apartment or perhaps a suburban neighborhood setting or even a rural or agricultural setting.

[1323.4s - 1344.7s]: And this is something you can weave into your practice as well. It's a beautiful way to reaffirm our commitment to the land for the upcoming annual cycle. And this is on January 6, which is essentially a fortnight two weeks after the winter solstice, the time when the sun is in that great returning cycle that's so important.

[1344.7s - 1349.0s]: We're going to be able to do this in a few months, literally and symbolically to so many of our traditions worldwide.

[1350.3s - 1366.3s]: We now are hosting a monthly online meetup. This is our regeneration Renaissance Roundtable, the first Sunday of each month. And we kick these off at 11.33 am Colorado time. That's mountain time.

[1366.3s - 1384.3s]: And the next one coming up is June 4th. If you want to join us, please do your most welcome. You can go to yonearth.org slash live to pre-register. And that's an evergreen link that resets each month to the new Zoom registration link for you.

[1384.8s - 1393.6s]: So you need to register each month and can do so immediately for the for the next online meetup on June 4th Sunday.

[1428.0s - 1444.3s]: We were recently invited by the Wilson and Suncini Law firm to give a presentation articulating over 50 specific simple daily things we can do at our homes and our places of work in order to have a better careful start.

[1478.0s - 1485.5s]: And the recording of those talks is also available on the blog page available for everybody. So you can check that out.

[1521.6s - 1530.2s]: One more video to mention. And this is our soon to be launched simple gardening wisdom video course.

[1547.0s - 1575.6s]: And this is such an important resource providing very simple easy to follow tips and tricks recommendations for you to use in your own garden, your own yard, your own farm perhaps to enhance your ability to produce wonderful food and herbal medicine and build soil and steward the land for all the critters, including the pollinators while you're enjoying your gardening practice.

[1585.1s - 1590.9s]: You can get it right now if you want. And it's on our store page on why on earth.org.

[1592.2s - 1603.5s]: And you know, this isn't meant so much to be an info commercial as an opportunity to pause and reflect and share that we've put together so many resources for you guys.

[1604.1s - 1617.7s]: And of course have many more coming, but just to take notice of all that we've been able to accomplish and put together for you thus far and really encourage you to take advantage of what we've made available.

[1639.4s - 1651.8s]: And I encourage you to like and subscribe if you like the information because that definitely helps us reach more people, the more that we get the likes and the subscriptions obviously as most of us are aware.

[1653.6s - 1661.6s]: So I'd like to pause and just take a moment to reflect, have a little tea here.

[1664.5s - 1669.8s]: Warm up. It's a bit chilly out with this beautiful rain.

[1672.0s - 1689.8s]: And I'm so grateful to be out here in the woods out of the office away from the buildings, able to really deepen into my connection and appreciation with the living natural world.

[1690.8s - 1716.5s]: And I so encourage you to deepen in that practice. I think perhaps more than anything else along with the love and kindness is for us to respond to this invitation to deepen our intimate relationship with Mother Nature, Ma Magaya, the trees, the grasses, the shrubs, the flowers.

[1719.3s - 1727.0s]: And perhaps connecting and befriending a particular tree is something that you can do to deepen your practice.

[1727.9s - 1735.7s]: Connecting with a particular body of water, it could be a pond or a lake or a stream or a river or even the ocean herself.

[1736.7s - 1758.6s]: These intimate relationships are not only with afford us, an insight into the supreme intelligence of nature, but also provide our own bodies and minds and spirits, a form of nourishment that is very hard to come by in our cities to be honest.

[1758.6s - 1766.5s]: And it's a form of nourishment that has a profound impact on our quality of life.

[1766.8s - 1778.0s]: One of the best things we can do to experience a richer, fuller, more joyful quality of life is frequently connect with nature, unplug and drop in.

[1778.0s - 1802.3s]: And if you like, you could even take a hike or a walk and perhaps sit and stay still in a particular spot for a while and observe what's going on with the insects, the critters, the plants, the soil, the birds, the air, maybe you'll be blessed by butterflies and perhaps even some honeybees and other pollinators.

[1803.3s - 1815.2s]: I have become increasingly convinced through my own experience that this frequent direct connection with nature is imperative, it's essential.

[1815.2s - 1833.3s]: And in Vereditas, one of the things that gets discussed in that exciting, eco-thriller story is the importance, especially in these times of connecting with AI with the authentic intelligence of Mamagaya of nature.

[1833.3s - 1862.3s]: And I'm convinced that not only is our connection with nature important for our well-being and our heart-centered ability to be good stewards, to care for the living world, it is also how we can access a particularly elegant and sophisticated and complex form of intelligence that is otherwise perhaps too elusive for us as humans to directly access in all of our constructed cities.

[1863.3s - 1869.8s]: And environments and economics and goings on in our rich human lives.

[1870.7s - 1892.9s]: So it's a deep invitation. And of course, one of my favorite terms, like this Greek term that is the origin, the etymological root for our words ecology and economy, point us in this direction of this relationship with the living world.

[1892.9s - 1896.8s]: And Eikos means home, it's our home, planet Earth, our home.

[1897.7s - 1903.3s]: And implicit in this term Eikos meaning home is also the concept of community.

[1904.1s - 1917.6s]: In ancient Greece, we would have referred to our dwelling as our Eikos and we would have also referred to the front room where we would receive guests and neighbors as the Eikos of the home, the Eikos of the Eikos.

[1917.6s - 1924.5s]: And so in this term is implicit, a notion of community and connection and relationship.

[1925.1s - 1938.5s]: And as we're going forward in the healing of our ecological relationships and our economic relationships and behaviors, an awareness of this term, Bueicos, is going to help light our path for us.

[1939.6s - 1952.7s]: Of course, the term humus meaning soil is another of my faves and it is connected at them, melodically to the words humor and humility and human even.

[1953.7s - 1966.7s]: So as we deepen into our understanding of our traditions, we come to understand that our human connection with soil is absolutely fundamental. It's in many of our creation stories.

[1967.7s - 1976.9s]: And when we're interacting physically with the living microbiome of the soil, that has an effect on our own neuro biochemistry.

[1977.5s - 1994.5s]: And we know that we experience enhanced immune system function, we experience elevated moods through enhanced serotonin production and even enhanced cognitive performance when we're on the regular in physical contact with the living soil.

[1994.5s - 2004.9s]: It can be through our bare hands, gardening, planting, flowers and herbs and vegetables. It can also be through our feet, walking barefoot around the soils, around the land.

[2005.8s - 2010.2s]: And all of that has this profound nourishment for us to access regularly.

[2012.5s - 2023.7s]: Another of my favorites is the term Weile, this middle English term means well-being and it's the same root that we get the word wealth from.

[2023.7s - 2035.9s]: So as we're exploring in our economic work, this regenerative renaissance is very much about reclaiming and redefining what we mean by wealth.

[2036.9s - 2057.1s]: Deep true sustained wealth, I would humbly posit for you is one rooted in relationship, in community, in our own well-being practices and our stewardship and regenerative work in our locations and worldwide.

[2058.7s - 2059.7s]: So there's Weile.

[2061.6s - 2064.2s]: Such a joy to share all of this with you.

[2064.8s - 2078.2s]: You know, one of the things, and I think I'll share here in a few minutes, why 133 is such a special number for me and so many of my friends and colleagues, our friends and colleagues.

[2079.6s - 2096.3s]: But it's such a beautiful opportunity to be connected with so many thought leaders and farmers and gardeners and herbalists and indigenous wisdom keepers and others working on this regenerative movement.

[2097.1s - 2106.9s]: And I'm struck having now interviewed so many experts that one thing's crystal clear and that is none of us has all the answers.

[2108.2s - 2122.5s]: Many of us have a lot of important knowledge and wisdom to share. No doubt about it. Many of us have deep expertise to share and we have the opportunity to learn so much from one another doing this work.

[2122.5s - 2130.0s]: But it is struck me that not one of us, at least nobody I've met yet has all of the answers.

[2130.8s - 2137.1s]: And if you know somebody who has all of the answers, please put me in touch. I'd love to interview her or him.

[2138.2s - 2159.7s]: But my sense is that the intelligence that we need, the ethos, the ethic that we need to cultivate and scale and deploy in this regenerative movement is distributed dispersed like a neuronal network, like the mycelial networks of the forest soils connecting the trees and the plants.

[2159.7s - 2169.6s]: So that it's not residing all in one node in one point. It is dispersed and distributed throughout the community.

[2170.3s - 2180.4s]: And that is part of the intelligent design of nature. That is part of the resilience built into the incredible fabric of the living biosphere.

[2181.4s - 2198.2s]: And it's part of how we get to understand and appreciate and learn from this incredible richness of insight and wisdom and knowledge among and between so many of our colleagues and friends and collaborators.

[2204.5s - 2228.2s]: The other thing that's clear to me is that we're all in this together. That we're in a process of transitioning, being invited to evolve beyond a way of living on the planet that has winners and losers into a way of being that has us understanding deeply that we are in this process.

We've got so many new resources to share with you as well and updates on a number of really exciting projects in development that will be rolling out in the coming weeks and months.

No, this is actually Colorado, not too far from Elkhruhn Farm and the town aligns the city of Boulder and a little farther away, the larger city of Denver.

Just up in the foothills here and we're having an usually wet rainy several days, which is most welcome for many of our farming and gardening friends getting the soils, the plants, the plants, the plants.
The starts freshly planted a really good drink of mama gaias nourishing waters.

We've also got culture and this of course includes how we interact with each other and I'll be speaking a little more about that sharing some of the insights and learnings I've had over the last several weeks and months with our podcast guests and other collaborating individuals and organizations.
